prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Lupus 1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust continuum polarization observations at Band 7 toward YSO in Lupus 1. The requested observations aim for a spatial resolution of 0.4 arcseconds and a large angular scale of 7.3 arcseconds. The targets were selected from Herschel+Spitzer maps of Rygl et al. (2013). The target names are not based on any catalogue. L1a is the only Class 0 source in Lupus and L1b/c/d/e are Class I sources.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We chose Band 7 observations because thermal dust emission has its brightest component in submillimeter wavelengths and Band 7 is the highest one allowed in polarization mode. The correlator setup is the only possible for polarization observations: TDM observations in full Stokes parameters.

Our goal is to observe how the dust polarization pattern changes from the dust envelope down to the circumstellar disk. Band 7 observations in configuration C36-3 gives an angular resolution of 0.4 arcseconds and a largest angular scale of 7.3 arcseconds (according to the Technical Handbook). At the Lupus distance, we will be able to trace the magnetic field from 1100 AU down to 60 AU physical scales. The proposed setup is thus sensitive either to the prominent envelope emission of the Class 0 sources and the prominent disk emission of the Class I sources. Even with the 1/3 primary beam restriction of polarization projects, the envelopes we trace are about 800 AU. Polarized emission more extended than that (if any) will be treated with caution.

The Class 0 source in our catalogue has peak flux density of 1.5 Jy/beam at single-dish resolution of 15 arcseconds (Shirley et al. 2000). We assume that 75% of the observed flux arises from the dust envelope, which means that 25% of the flux comes from a putative disk (e. g. Rao et al. 2014). Therefore, a 100 AU circumstellar disk (0.67 arcseconds at the Lupus distance) will have an intensity of 365 mJy. Scaling this flux down to the requested resolution (0.4 arcseconds), the expected peak flux is 130 mJy/beam. Assuming a conservative 1% polarization, and in order to detect the half maximum of the peak in a 10-sigma level, the requested rms is 0.060 mJy/beam. For the more evolved (Class I) sources, the disk has a more prominent contribution to the total flux than in Class 0 sources, so we expect an even stronger detection. The total requested time fits within the minimum 3 hours time for polarization proposals.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Orion A
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Dust continuum polarization observations at Band 7 toward YSO in Orion A. The requested observations aim for a spatial resolution of 0.16 arcseconds and a large angular scale of 2.2 arcseconds. This setup was chosen to match the physical scales of the "Lupus 1" Science Goal. The targets were selected from Herschel+Spitzer maps of Megeath et al. (2012), Stutz et al. (2013) and ammonia data from the GAS project. The target names are not based on any catalogue. Orion-a is a Class 0 source, the remaining sources are catalogued as protostars at either Class 0 or I phases, without distinction (Megeath et al. 2012).

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We chose Band 7 observations because thermal dust emission has its brightest component in submillimeter wavelengths and Band 7 is the highest one allowed in polarization mode. The correlator setup is the only possible for polarization observations: TDM observations in full Stokes parameters.

Our goal is to observe how the dust polarization pattern changes from the dust envelope down to the circumstellar disk. Band 7 observations in configuration C36-5 gives an angular resolution of 0.16 arcseconds and a largest angular scale of 2.2 arcseconds (according to the Technical Handbook). At the Orion distance, we will be able to trace the magnetic field from 925 AU down to 65 AU physical scales (similar to the Lupus Science Goal). The proposed setup is thus sensitive either to the prominent envelope emission of the Class 0 sources and the prominent disk emission of the Class I sources. The largest angular scale traced at such configuration is already smaller than 1/3 of the primary beam at band 7, so this restriction for polarization projects is not an issue for this Science Goal.

The Class 0 source in the catalogue of Stutz et al. (2013) has peak flux density of 2.5 Jy/beam at the single-dish resolution of 19 arcseconds. We assume that 75% of the observed flux arises from the dust envelope, which means that 25% of the flux comes from a putative disk (e. g. Rao et al. 2014). Therefore, a 100 AU circumstellar disk (0.24 arcseconds at the Orion distance) will have an intensity of 625 mJy. Scaling this flux down to the requested resolution (0.16 arcseconds), the expected peak flux is 275 mJy/beam. Assuming a conservative 1% polarization, and in order to obtain an uniform sensitivity for the whole project, we request an rms of 0.060 mJy/beam (which is the same sensitivity of the Lupus 1 Science Goal). The requested rms will trace polarized emission at the half maximum of the peak in a 25-sigma level. For the more evolved (Class I) sources, the disk has a more prominent contribution to the total flux than in Class 0 sources, so we expect an even stronger detection. The total requested time fits within the minimum 3 hours time for polarization proposals

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: The role of magnetic fields in the dynamical evolution of Young Stellar Objects (YSOs) is not yet fully understood due to the lack of high spatial resolution polarization observations. While models point to disk suppression in rotating magnetized cores, observations show no clear correlation between outflows, magnetic fields and rotational axis at 1000 AU scales. We propose to obtain a detailed view of magnetic fields in YSOs located in Lupus 1 and Orion A. Both clouds are immersed in a highly magnetized medium although the two clouds have different regime of interstellar feedback. We have selected 11 sources, Class 0 and Class I objects, so we can inspect the polarization from the dust envelope and from circumstellar disks. We will be able to trace the morphological transition in the B-field between the two populations and verify how it affects the core dynamics (such as fragmentation degree and core angular momentum). We plan to compare the polarization data with molecular line observations from the Green Bank Ammonia Survey and obtain a detailed view of the YSOs kinematics.
